I support a world based in true diversity completely, and with a world being slowly reduced to a genderless confrontation less danger less world, it would be absolute death of what it is to be human. Who would ghandi or MLK have been in a perfect world. Normal.

I would still rate this as a great advert now. The idea is still solid, just because it's not in line with the progressive ideas of 2019 it doesn't mean it's not a clever campaign. I don't, in any way, disagree with stamping on toxic masculinity... but I do think that people need to relax and take life less seriously.

I suppose you open yourself up the criticism using “Men” as it’s not as inclusive, but if “masculinity” is more salient I’d say you’ve got your bases covered. I think they’re great, by the way.

I think we gotta be careful about useing #metoo as shorthand for different debates.
It was founded by Taran Burke in 2006 to raise awareness about sexual harassment. The two are linked, but this question is more specifically about using (weaponising) gender norms in advertising. To my eye, this ad neatly excludes over half of the potenial market - possibly that’s he creators’ ideal outcome, hard to tell without seeing the brief. I agree with commenters above in that the same concept applied to girls would feel *utterly* cringey and creepy(-er than this one is). Man here is almost an accolade. Kinda tells everything I need to know.

Some lovely photography and image manipulation. If it hit the brief, and resonated with who vw considered its target audience then it's great. The female in our agency is the one who likes drives fast, and thinks she collected thinks she collected a bumper number of speeding tickets in 2005.
Forget metoo this is a tad creepy like “girls who were always women” PEDO dreams 🤢🤮🤮🤮🤮🤮 kids are kids

@makwete.barco @d_and_ad Think these are the shining comments in this discussion. Nothing is saying that this kind of representation is something we should wholly dismantle, rather... acknowledging a tired narrative we’re all familiar with. Asking for inclusiveness in modern media, or to reach farther to the underrepresented is a courageous (and necessary) next step. We know this story already, now let’s move forward. Shouldn’t we be asking how we invite others to participate in a modern day dialogue instead of reaching for the same old audiences time and time and time again? Everyone is worthy of representation.
Thank you for posting this.

In my opinion, as a female, I don’t see why this should be looked down upon in the ‘me too’ era or more so why this would offend anyone. If anything, I would see the LGBTQI community possibly kicking it up a stink but SHIT, how many people can one advert try and please these days!? 🙄 The imagery shows a little boy doing boy-like things, which also happens to correlate to what most men will do. People look way into things like this and everyone is way over sensitive nowadays. Sure, some boys like doing different things and not all girls like dresses. But, I think it’s ok to stereotype the majority for quite a cute ad and something that really isn’t trying to offend anyone, rather show quite a common behavioral trend in male behavior. #GetOverIt #HyperSensitive
Don’t see the problem with these... even today

Are these boys demonstrating misogyny or toxic masculinity? Seems like they are just like many boys who are naturally “butch” on the spectrum of gender identity. Rock n roll, fast cars are actually really fucking fun for a lot of people and some of them are heteronormative, some are not. The copy might be a little off but the idea that some boys are predisposed to play loud music and drive fast is simply one type of male state and to pretend it’s not ins just stupid and unrealistic. By the way women, and LGBTQ individuals are also predisposed to these same an super fun behaviors. Chill the fuck out.

@makwete.barco I think you make a good and interesting point, as do many others in this thread. The point that just because we culturally have a new way of understanding/accepting what it means to be one gender or another, does not necessarily mean there are those that stop feeling a particular way about how they identify; it doesn't have to be one way or the other, rather one of a number of ways to express your identity. Even so, in that light the strapline of this particular campaign becomes problematic because it still only really implies one way to be masculine. This is a really interesting thread!

Would be nice to see companies use stereotypes in a more whimsical, comedic fashion like this, rather than using them as examples of toxic social constructs etc.
@mathieu_deneen_photography 👌🏼 the way you address the theme is very forward thinking. kuddos!
Calling this debatable or improper would be ridiculous

I saw some comments that said it's not wrong to be male. This is not about gender. This is about the social construct that is masculinity. The ads portray characteristics that define masculinity. Literaly define. Because the stick gender to sex. In the first picture you can see a boy peeing which is natural. Pants down because it's funny. But he's looking at his right carelessly and also as if he's doing something rebellious instead of peeing in a potty. It's the attitude towards the action. Little kids have different behaviours based on their personality but they are trained to act masculine. We should teach them not to care about that and instead, act like a correct civilian. Now imagine a grown up doing that. It looks totally reckless. The second picture makes it worse because it is saying "masculinity is about being aggressive for the show" and also male is being a rockstar. No. The third one is about fixing things. As if a girl doesn't know about how to fix things as a car and has to depend on a man to do so. Knowledge is genderless. Don't make one of your kids ever depend on someone to do something. It's not healthy. And for the fourth photo, you can tell that the way that arm is in there is the same as a man in a car that has an oblivious and powerful attitude. Like a "oh just passing by in my car, because being a man is having a car and feeling powerful over others", which nowadays would sound shallow and also narcissistic. The only thing about this that is genius is the way the photography is treated. With a strong aesthetic that nowadays brings back memories. But remember we were taught this. And it's not okay. (Sorry if I wrote badly, English is not my first language).
Behave , it was 2005 not 1975. It would have been seen as reductive and old fashioned back then too

@mariakivs agree to all the above, just don’t see the specific value of coupling it to metoo (as opposed to a general awakening of gender politics.) I think metoo is fat too important to dilute it to 3 year old boys peeing in a potty... catch my drift?

The problem with this ad is that the tagline excludes. It’s realistic to have an audience in mind, and it’s realistic that some boys do become the kind of men portrayed in this ad, but it is negatively exclusive to use a tagline like “For boys who were always men”. People and brands who talk or think like this only demonstrate that they have a limited understanding and perspective of the world. 
This message could be suitable for some brands, but definitely not for a brand with considerable reach like Volkswagen. 
There are so many different kinds of men. It’s a bad brand move to not consider this.

@mathieu_deneen_photography I don’t think anyone is denying that there are different genders in the world - what we are currently seeing (thanks to me too etc) is the fact that you don’t automatically define ‘being a man’ by one’s desire for cars or being a rock star. And in this sense, this campaign - and all other campaigns that maintain conventional gender symbols - is not just outdated and boring, also potentially detrimental to all genders and individuals within them.
Have 'boys' and 'men' become taboos? I'm sure research showed they were aiming at a male demographic. My son and I stand up to pee, I would hope nobody feels sexually violated by that!
The worlds gotten too serious for its own good
That would applies better for a motorcycle brand, at least, a muscle car... a Porsche 911 or an American V8 @fernando6omez @carol_rules

@d_and_ad I don’t expect everyone to understand each other but we can all respect each other and  all shades of the human experience. We all have different levels of masculinity, femininity, androgyny, sexuality. But to ignore that there is a maleness or femaleness or otherness is just as wrong as exaggerating it. Respect and common sense... i think this post sensationalizes a pretty vanilla ad campaign is all and there are cases of far more harmful stereotyping out there. Addressing metoo here is not doing them any justice and pushes ignorant people to continue being ignorant.

I see it as a positive fact, it means society is evolving. I drove a Golf GTI for a while, thus I would like to be included in the message. At the end this ad is about having attitude, any human being can have it despite the gender.
This discussion is stupid.

@d_and_ad I feel that currently we need more representation of humanity as a whole - no matter how we self identify, at the crux of all of our physical differences, (the one thing that probably matters the least and divides us the most) we’re all human. It’s been refreshing to see ads if differently abled people, of mixed family’s and cis and trans people, of everyone. Working in advertising means we have a powerful platform for change. Yes, it would help if our agencies were more diverse, but we just need to work towards putting out creative that is representative of the spaces we all live in and occupy - they’re not all just black and white, or cis, hereto and able bodied. They’re all worthy of representation.

Sometimes it’s appropriate to ask why. These are norms because they are relatable. We know these men. It says nothing about their opinions or ideals. It reflects actions of certain men that the product is targeting. Men and women are biologically different in the majority of cases. To say the genders are the same and difference shouldn’t be commented on shouldn’t be the focus. Surely the arguments around gender should start to be put into logical context soon. Lovely ads. Image 1  and 4 especially.
This is creativity. Don't make it political. Criticizing it would be like asking David to cover his lil Jon. This is a superb campaign and yes it is positive.
@digitalbloomnyc do you see this as a positive or think it holds back open discourse?
@makwete.barco Great point! do you feel we need more representation of traditional gender norms within advertising? How can creative work be  inclusive across all fronts?

Love the art direction. Takes me back when times were easier as a little rascal😂 ..however, the "boys Will be boys" is definitively a "truth" worth and important to challenge. @d_and_ad

@harrypsj interesting point. How did you feel about the recent Gillette ad?

What?! This post is such a disservice to the metoo movement. Yes this sort of reinforces gender stereotypes and might lack taste by today’s standards,  but it is a far cry from me too. Is it politically incorrect to be male now? Would it be wrong if the copy said “for girls who were always women”? Accept and love all walks of life and beyond all respect each other... this ad campaign does not disrespect anyone so let it be. Clumping this ad together with metoo belittles the focus of the movement.

I don’t think we should rush to dismantle “traditional” gender norms. It’s possible to be accepting of a new and different ways of being human (male, female, trans, cis, however you identify) without labeling the traditional as crude or somehow no longer worthy of our current time.
